text: Table of Contents Chapter 1 - ENDINGS Chapter 2 - FROM THE ASHES Chapter 3 - THE RAVEN TOWER Chapter 4 - A FRESH START OR AN OLD PROBLEM Chapter 5 - A PLACE OF PRIDE Chapter 6 - LUNCH WITH THE ENEMY Chapter 7 - A TIME TO PREPARE Chapter 8 - THE TEST BEFORE THE TEST Chapter 9 - INTO THE FIRES Chapter 10 - THE OTHER KIND OF PAIN Chapter 11 - THE NATURE OF BONDS Chapter 12 - TO WALK AN OLD PATH Chapter 13 - A CHALLENGING PAST Chapter 14 - THE ORDER Chapter 15 - DARK SHADOWS Chapter 16 - TO RAISE A SWORD Epilogue - BEGININGS Resources About the author.
Name: Book 9

text: Move along, move along, Rodregas said.
Name: Book 9

text: He prodded the prisoner up the roughly hewn stone steps none too gently with the butt end of the lit torch in his hand.
Name: Book 9

text: "We dont have all night.
Name: Book 9

text: The rough handling of the prisoner seemed like a brash act for a man of sixty years, since the young man could have broken him in half with ease if he chose to do so.
Name: Book 9

text: He was powerfully built, and towered head and shoulders over Rodregas.
Name: Book 9

text: In fact the man looked rather like the hero from a bard's tale, with his square jaw and short black curls and fine dark eyes.
Name: Book 9

text: In contrast Rodregas sported a bulging paunch, scrawny legs and loose teeth which gave him fits when he chewed on anything harder than a half-baked wheat cake.
Name: Book 9

text: Rodregas' confidence in the prisoner's lack of retaliation came from the expression of dazed uncertainty on the man's face, a look he recognized on other prisoners whose world came crashing down around them without warning, whose lives changed forever in the blink of an eye.
Name: Book 9

text: It was hard to feel sorry for the young man; since he was the kind of fellow Rodregas had lost out to all his life.
Name: Book 9

text: Somewhere in the recesses of his soul, though, a glimmer of compassion flashed forth; if only because of what awaited the prisoner.
Name: Book 9

text: On the other hand, knowing what was to befall the female prisoner mounting the stairs behind him thrust Rodregas deeper into a foul mood.
Name: Book 9

text: Her long auburn hair fell in waves about her shoulders, and her startling green eyes were almost too large for her angular face.
Name: Book 9

text: Her skin was the golden hue of the High AElves, the most magically powerful of all the Ijosalfar people.
Name: Book 9

text: Although her auburn hair and her slim athletic build marked her as a half-breed, a woman such as she drew many an appreciative stare.
Name: Book 9

text: She was not beautiful in a way that Rodregas was used to, yet the odd combination of her features captivated Rodregas.
Name: Book 9

text: She was young and her innate abilities in the magical arts were thought to be immense.
Name: Book 9

text: At the moment the possibility that she would ever achieve such power diminished with each step nearer the tower roof.

frame.Frame: Cause  change  of  position  on  a  scale

Name: Book 9

text: Her eyes were alert, and she gazed around her for an opportunity to escape.
Name: Book 9

text: The gag on her mouth and the iron bands on her arms prevented her from calling on her magic to help her.
Name: Book 9

text: Sergeant," said the other guard.
Name: Book 9

text: "If we dont hurry them, we will feel the master's wrath when we get to the top.
Name: Book 9

text: Rodregas grunted in agreement, I will double your ration of food tonight and it will be fresh if you move a little faster," he said to the prisoners.

frame.Frame: Cause  change  of  position  on  a  scale

Name: Book 9

text: With that hope dangling before them, both prisoners climbed faster up the stairs.
Name: Book 9

text: Rodregas thought the other guard was going to laugh out loud at his comment.
Name: Book 9

text: As a senior guard familiar with the impending ceremony, the fellow damned well knew that neither prisoner would be worrying about food within the hour.
Name: Book 9

text: Rodregas groaned to himself as the group picked up the pace on the tower steps.
Name: Book 9

text: Over the last few years, his right knee acted up whenever he mounted stairs.
Name: Book 9

text: That, of course, was just one of many complaints advanced years bestowed upon him.
Name: Book 9

text: How ironic that the young prisoners were on their way to die, when old useless men like him, and scumbag fellow guards, continued to live.
Name: Book 9

text: He suppressed a shiver of excitement at the notion that this time will be different.
Name: Book 9

text: This time, he would not just cry out to the gods about the injustice while innocent people burned.
Name: Book 9

text: He filled his lungs with stale air tainted with burning pitch and tried to sink into the mindless guard mentality that kept him functioning for the past decade and a half.
Name: Book 9

text: Once a man loses all hope of a decent life, it is astonishing what he will do to stay alive.
Name: Book 9

text: For the last twenty years his following orders and doing his duty, along with his better than average training for a guard, had served him well.
Name: Book 9

text: He had been safe from the bounty on his head and for the most part.
Name: Book 9

text: His life was more boring than anything else.
Name: Book 9

text: He approached the door to the tower roof with the prisoners.
Name: Book 9

text: Instead of formulating a plan of action his mind kept going back to the horror of last week's practice when his master, Ravenhurr, demanded a rehearsal of the ritual ceremony with the senior guards.
Name: Book 9

text: At the time he assumed they would merely walk through the procedure.
Name: Book 9

text: Ravenhurr, however, was the kind of man who demanded perfection.
Name: Book 9

text: He demanded it both in himself and from those around him.
Name: Book 9

text: That perfection required no less than an exact replication of the ceremony.
Name: Book 9

text: As usual, he acceded to his master's wishes and did as he was told.
Name: Book 9

text: He knew the value of following orders and it had kept him alive so far.
Name: Book 9

text: When he placed his hand on the tower door an involuntary shudder racked his body at the idea of following those orders one more time.
Name: Book 9

text: He looked over again at the AElven maiden.
Name: Book 9

text: To an exotic beauty like her a balding overweight man like himself would be invisible under normal circumstances.
Name: Book 9

text: Some of the other guards might be tempted to take what would not be given, but not him.
Name: Book 9

text: Like his mother always told him, a person did not have to own a beautiful sunset to enjoy watching it.
Name: Book 9

text: The door to the top of Raven Tower was large and deeply carved in intricate designs and runes.
Name: Book 9

text: Though as a youth Rodregas had trained in the basics of magic, a secret he was careful not to share, the magical runes were far beyond his understanding.
Name: Book 9

text: He led the prisoners through the door and walked out onto the top of the tower.
Name: Book 9

text: The circular roof was flat and open to the sky.
Name: Book 9

text: The only covering was the landing for the stairs in the East corner.
Name: Book 9

text: The cool night air refreshed his spirits somewhat.
Name: Book 9

text: Before the prisoners could look around, he shoved them to the right side and strode over to Ravenhurr, who was peering into the night sky through a long tube with tiny glass panes at each end.
Name: Book 9

text: Ravenhurr loved to boast that the tube brought the stars closer to him.
Name: Book 9

text: He was never one to hurry about anything, at least not before tonight.
Name: Book 9

text: At that moment, though, his lean body quivered with excitement.
Name: Book 9

text: Master," Rodregas said, with a respectful bow, "The prisoners are ready.
Name: Book 9

text: His eyes passed over Rodregas to glance at the prisoners.
Name: Book 9

text: He nodded without a word and went back to peering through the tube.
Name: Book 9

text: Rodregas had never understood how the stars in the night sky could make the world closer or farther away from the Celestial Realm, where the Gods lived, or how that could affect magic, but he knew the placement of the stars was critical to the success of the ceremony tonight.
Name: Book 9

text: Ravenhurr was an attractive man, like most of the Immortalist Sorcerers.
Name: Book 9

text: After all, if you can pick your body, why would you ever choose an ugly one.
Name: Book 9

text: Rodregas looked over again at the man that he had brought up the stairs.
Name: Book 9

text: With the ability to select your body you would choose someone like that: attractive, talented and a natural athlete.
Name: Book 9

text: Rodregas stood to the side waiting for Ravenhurrs signal.
Name: Book 9

text: Ravenhurr raised his head up from the tube again and scanned the rooftop making sure all the parts of the ceremony were in place.
Name: Book 9

text: Rodregas had always thought that it was only Ravenhurrs eyes that gave away the fact that what was inside him was not as attractive as his exterior.
Name: Book 9

text: Ravenhurrs eyes had an intensity about them, a habit of weighing everyone else and finding them wanting.
Name: Book 9

text: Rodregas felt that Ravenhurr saw in everyone else a lesser person whose best function was to be used by his betters.
Name: Book 9

text: Rodregas looked over the rooftop following Ravenhurrs eyes.
Name: Book 9

text: Most of the open flat roof of the tower was covered in various circles.
Name: Book 9

text: The largest circle held all the others and was made of a glittering white sand-like substance.
Name: Book 9

text: Its diameter had been drawn as large as possible within the limitations of the roofs edges.
Name: Book 9

text: On the inside were sigils, runes, and small candles set out every few feet.
Name: Book 9

text: Rodregas knew enough of magic to understand that the purpose of this circle was to keep out unwanted magical influences.
Name: Book 9

text: They could interfere with the spell casting inside the circle.
Name: Book 9

text: Also, the circle would hold in any magical forces inside which someone wanted to store or manipulate.
Name: Book 9

text: Inside the large circle were four smaller circles.
Name: Book 9

text: Rodregas eyes immediately went to the one on the north side made of blue sand, where inside sigils made of a yellow waxy substance laid a giant lion.
Name: Book 9

text: This was not a normal lion such as those found in the nearby forest, but a giant beast.
Name: Book 9

text: Ravenhurr had been lucky indeed.
Name: Book 9

text: He had been able to buy several Dire Cats from the Immortalist Guild dealer Taiga.
Name: Book 9

text: With magic, he caused them to go into heat.
Name: Book 9

text: It was known to be very difficult to affect Dire beasts with magic, and his success had shown his power and accomplishment as a mage.
Name: Book 9

text: Rodregas had regretted not being on duty when the Dire Cats were staked out on the roof.
Name: Book 9

text: Rodregas had heard from the other guards that the cats were in heat, and as Ravenhurr had hoped, a Celestial Lion had sensed their presence while the lion was out during the full moon with the Wilde Hunt, and the great lion had spent the last few nights doing his best to impregnate both of the female beasts.
Name: Book 9

text: The whole keep could hear the wild rutting going on.
Name: Book 9

text: Ravenhurr then had goats released on the roof and the Celestial Lion had gorged himself on them when he had finished rutting.
Name: Book 9

text: The well-satisfied beast lay limp, sleeping, confident in his celestial power, and oblivious to his surroundings.
Name: Book 9

text: He lied unbound, as required by the ceremony.
Name: Book 9

text: Rodregas assumed some subtle magic had been used to influence the beast to sleep in just the right spot.
Name: Book 9

text: The unlikely success of having an actual celestial animal as part of the ceremony had put Ravenhurr into an unusually good mood.
Name: Book 9

text: Using one of the Dire Cats in the ceremony would have been good, but an actual Celestial animal would provide much more power.
Name: Book 9

text: Rodregas hands clutched into a fist at his side as he could not help thinking that the last thing the world needed was for Ravenhurr, or any of the Immortalists, to acquire more power.
Name: Book 9

text: Rodregas knew there was almost no opposition to the Immortalist left, but futile as it would probably be Rodregas could no longer go along with their immoral acts.
Name: Book 9

text: Rodregas pulled his thoughts back to the roof.
Name: Book 9

text: He would only have one shot at this.
Name: Book 9

text: In a fair fight no mortal was a match for one of the Immortalists.
Name: Book 9

text: Luckily, thought Rodregas, I have no intention of playing fair.
Name: Book 9

text: The two female Dire Cats that had been used to lure the Celestial Lion to the tower had fascinated Rodregas since Ravenhurr, at the expense of a very large part of his fortune, had been able to purchase them from the Immortalist Guild dealer Taiga.
Name: Book 9

text: When Rodregas looked into their eyes he had seen a greater understanding than that possessed by mere animals.
Name: Book 9

text: When they growled, it felt like the earth trembled.
Name: Book 9

text: When Rodregas had seen the Dire Cats in their cage he had not been able to imagine a more powerful lion.
Name: Book 9

text: The Celestial Lion was simply breathtaking; almost twice as large as the Dire Cats and even more powerfully built.
Name: Book 9

text: It was not simply size that set him apart however.
Name: Book 9

text: It was a way of moving, a grace that spoke of perfection.
Name: Book 9

text: To look at a Celestial Beast made Rodregas wish he could write poetry like some noble in one of the high western courts; it made him struggle for words that he simply did not have.
Name: Book 9

text: And what did this marvelous beast do.
Name: Book 9

text: Rutted, gorged, and fell asleep ready for the slaughter.
Name: Book 9

text: Rodregas could not help but shake his head at how life can show you miracles that made you want to live again, and that using the same miracle drives home the fact that there is truly no justice to existence.
Name: Book 9

text: His eyes jerked back to Ravenhurr, as the sorcerer made a jerking motion, rising up from his sky tube.
Name: Book 9

text: Now, he said and quickly repeated in his deep but smooth voice, NOW.
Name: Book 9

text: Captain Poir, the leader of Ravenhurrs guards, had stepped out of the shadows and approached the prisoners, but Rodregas stepped forward first and grabbed the half AElf maidens arm.
Name: Book 9

text: With a quick twist of the key he removed her iron shackles but grabbed her arm hard so she could not run.
Name: Book 9

text: This way, Rodregas said to her.
Name: Book 9

text: As he separated her from the male prisoner he whispered to her, If you want to live, dont do anything until your circle starts to burn, then I will throw the club at the other guard.
Name: Book 9

text: Run and make sure you get out of the circle.
Name: Book 9

text: She jerked towards him as he spoke and Rodregas was struck once again by the beauty of her amazing eyes, but he forced her forward hoping that she could think on her feet.
Name: Book 9

text: Rodregas carefully led her over the outer white circle and into a yellow circle that was across from the Celestial Lion.
Name: Book 9

text: Captain Poir led the man into the pale green circle that was the closest to being in the exact middle and was most strongly interconnected to the other circles.
Name: Book 9

text: As Rodregas crossed into the main circle, the sense of power almost made him stumble.
Name: Book 9

text: He knew his own power was minimal, not much above average, but his few years of training as a boy had opened him up to magic more than the other three guards on the tower roof.
Name: Book 9

text: Rodregas knew that if Ravenhurr had ever thought he had more than basic magic training he would long have been reassigned to a duty far from the ceremony.
Name: Book 9

text: The very air seemed to strum like a stringed instrument with the gathered magical power.
Name: Book 9

text: Rodregas could not help but think about how out of his depth he was trying to interfere with the ritual ceremony.
Name: Book 9

text: However, as he forced the beautiful woman forward, the woman whose name he had refused to learn, he knew he was indeed going to try.
Name: Book 9

text: I will do it this time, Rodregas thought to himself, This time I will not choose my survival over others.
Name: Book 9

text: His life was not worth living if he did nothing again; he wanted to feel at least a small measure of being the man he had been raised to be.
Name: Book 9

text: Celestial Gods, please let my life be worth something in death, if not in life, he prayed quietly.
Name: Book 9

text: Captain Poir and Rodregas carefully put the two prisoners in the middle of their circles, and then stepped out.
Name: Book 9

text: They each picked up small wooden clubs.
Name: Book 9

text: Dale and Junnit stood across from the two of them holding matching clubs.
Name: Book 9

text: The ceremony required the prisoners to stay in each circle unbound.
Name: Book 9

text: The job of the guards was to remain outside the circle but make sure that the prisoners stayed inside.
Name: Book 9

text: Metal would interfere with the magic so the guards held simple wooden clubs and wore only linen clothes with no metal fastenings.
Name: Book 9

text: As Rodregas pushed the half AElf into her circle, making sure not to disturb the bluish sand covered in swirls of colorful small crystals, he was surprised at how vulnerable he felt without his armor but readied himself for the task at hand.
Name: Book 9

text: He quickly reached out to the woman and pulled off her gag, as even that would count as a binding and would interfere with the ritual.
Name: Book 9

text: He wanted to whisper to her as he removed it, and give her a hint of the desperate gambit that he was about to try, but he knew that it was not worth the risk of others overhearing.
Name: Book 9

text: Both of their lives depended on her doing what Rodregas had told her.
Name: Book 9

text: If he succeeded, she would know what Rodregas had done; if he failed, well he was familiar enough with that feeling.
Name: Book 9

text: He saw her lips forming something under her breath, probably a spell, but she did not have time to execute a spell of sufficient strength in the time left her.
Name: Book 9

text: Magic took too long to prepare to be useful so quickly.
Name: Book 9

text: Ravenhurr stepped into the last circle; the one made entirely of what appeared to be fresh blood and of symbols made from the careful placement of living organs.
Name: Book 9

text: Rodregas breathed in deeply, trying to settle himself, and almost gagged from the smells: the stench of fresh blood, the scent of fear from the prisoners, the smell of power, and other smells that he could not identify.
Name: Book 9

text: Rodregas closed down on himself, Duty, he thought.
Name: Book 9

text: My real duty this time, focus on the next step.
Name: Book 9

text: I can do this.
Name: Book 9

text: As Rodregas raised the club, he kept his eyes away from the AElf maiden not wanting to give himself away to anyone watching.
Name: Book 9

text: Gods, Rodregas quietly prayed.
Name: Book 9

text: You have never answered my prayers.
Name: Book 9

text: I have never had much to give you as an offering of wealth to your temples, nor have I done great deeds in your names, but if any of you hate these life-stealing Immortalists as I do, then let me know your favor.
Name: Book 9

text: Rodregas could not help but add a selfish plea to his desperate prayer, If by your grace I live, then I promise you gods that I will make it my lifes duty to fight the Life Stealers.
Name: Book 9

text: Rodregas doubted his prayers would do any good, but if nothing else he was a practical man and when you are pushing the odds it never hurts to call in divine favor.
Name: Book 9

text: Rodregas knew things would start moving quickly now.
Name: Book 9

text: Ravenhurr had been preparing the circles for months, feeding them with unearthly energies.
Name: Book 9

text: Ravenhurr had not wanted the prisoners up on the tower roof until the last moment, lest their fear lead them to take desperate action.
Name: Book 9

text: Ravenhurr started to speak the final words of the spell, setting off months of careful preparations.
Name: Book 9

text: Rodregas knew that sorcerers use ancient languages so that others who might be watching cannot understand what they are saying and guess their intent beforehand.
Name: Book 9

text: During the practice walk-through the week before, Ravenhurr had spoken the same words that he started to utter now.
Name: Book 9

text: Ravenhurrs deep, melodious voice rumbled out, Spitualu seperatia orgirgia turia, and the middle, pale green circle started to burn.
Name: Book 9

text: Rodregas could not pronounce the ancient version of the Eastern Common language Ravenhurr was using, but he thought that he understood the gist of the meaning.
Name: Book 9

text: Rodregas could not believe the man did not try to battle his way out.
Name: Book 9

text: The captain and Dale were both large men but it would have been very difficult to keep such a gifted athlete in the circle, even with clubs, if he was determined to escape.
Name: Book 9

text: However, he was young and clearly lacked battle experience.
Name: Book 9

text: He seemed unsure of what to do.
Name: Book 9

text: Then it was too late; the blue flames of the circle rose high, then inward, and engulfed him.
Name: Book 9

text: The young man started to split in two.
Name: Book 9

text: The physical man stood there, but as he watched, another ethereal version, the mans spirit, his very non-corporal essence, was suddenly pulled from his body, and then whipped around and out of the burning circle.
Name: Book 9

text: Rodregas was not sure, but as this ethereal version of the man was pulled apart, Rodregas thought he could see him screaming.
Name: Book 9

text: Rodregas pulled his eyes away from the horrifying vision as the corporal man went from looking confused and unsure to having no expression at all, like an empty piece of meat.
Name: Book 9

text: Rodregass eyes flinched away from the terrible sight as he felt he might scream in horror and fury at what was happening.
Name: Book 9

text: Then Ravenhurr yelled out, Spirea faira podia turiana, and the circle holding the Celestial Lion started to burn in the same blue flames, the blue flames that make up the creation forces of life that can only be called up when the Celestial Realm was close.
Name: Book 9

text: Suddenly the sleeping lion looked up in surprise and started to growl and then he started to burn.
Name: Book 9

text: Rodregas had seen enough of lesser versions of the ritual to expect it, but to watch it was amazing.
Name: Book 9

text: The circle blazed with an intense heat that blasted his face and the magnificent creature inside blazed with blue creation fire.
Name: Book 9

text: It was a sudden and violent and primal process.
Name: Book 9

text: The lion started to stand up and then simply fell apart into blazing blue energy.
Name: Book 9

text: That energy surged out of the circle and swirled around inside the larger outer circle.
Name: Book 9

text: Every hair on Rodregas body stood at attention.
Name: Book 9

text: Then the blue flaming energy was sucked into the pale green circle.
Name: Book 9

text: There the prisoner, now empty of his own essence, stood still.
Name: Book 9

text: As the blue fire was sucked into his body, the corporal body suddenly seemed more solid than before.
Name: Book 9

text: Once more Ravenhurr yelled out in his melodious voice the trigger words for the next part of the ritual, Mana faria podia ricoria.
Name: Book 9

text: It was now or never for Rodregas to strike.
Name: Book 9

text: Rodregas raised his arm up and threw his club forward with all his strength.
Name: Book 9

text: There was no time to see if his club hit Junnit or if the half AElfin maiden ran.
Name: Book 9

text: Rodregas half ran and half jumped to the next circle, where Ravenhurr stood with raised arms.
Name: Book 9

text: Ravenhurr was focused on his inner magic and was not prepared for his own guards sudden action.
Name: Book 9

text: Rodregas grabbed Ravenhurrs arm and his belt, and using his weight and momentum against Ravenhurr, threw him bodily into the circle of colorful crystals where the half AElf maiden had stood moments ago.
Name: Book 9

text: Ravenhurr, in an amazing act of balance, almost caught himself.
Name: Book 9

text: He seemed to defy gravity as he hung in the air.
Name: Book 9

text: Rodregas tried to reach out to push Ravenhurr into the circle, but before his hand touched the sorcerer, Ravenhurr lost his balance and fell into the circle.
Name: Book 9

text: The moment that Ravenhurr crossed into the circle he started to burn.
Name: Book 9

text: His body twisted in pain as he burned the same blue fire of creation that he had called forth to rip apart a mans soul and steal the physical essence of a Celestial Lion.
Name: Book 9

text: The flames that he had called forth to steal the AElfin maidens magical abilities now burned him.
Name: Book 9

text: The timing had been near impossible.
Name: Book 9

text: The spell calling forth the flames of creation could only burn one life.
Name: Book 9

text: But the timing was perfect; Ravenhurr called forth the fire, and then he was in it.
Name: Book 9

text: The flames consumed his body in seconds, and flaring from the circle went the multi-colored energy of his magic, the one element that the circle was designed to protect from the flames.
Name: Book 9

text: His magic power shot out of the circle and started orbiting the larger circle.
Name: Book 9

text: He was completely gone.
Name: Book 9

text: Rodregas excitedly thought, Victory.
Name: Book 9

text: He had done it.
Name: Book 9

text: He had killed the Immortalist Sorcerer Ravenhurr.
Name: Book 9

text: The multi-colored energy of his magic swirled around the outer circle and was sucked into the empty vessel of the young man.
Name: Book 9

text: The magic energy throbbed and Rodregas could feel the ritual screaming for the final release of the magic; there was no way to save anyone else.
Name: Book 9

text: Rodregas would probably die in the next few seconds in the magical backlash of the failed spell, but he thought that he had understood the meaning of the final trigger words used in the rehearsal.
Name: Book 9

text: Rodregas years of rejecting his early upbringing made him embarrassed to say the words, but he reached down into that deep, nearly empty place where his little bit of power still sparked.
Name: Book 9

text: Rodregas reached deep inside and pulled that spark of power up until he felt the tingle and inner sensation that he always inelegantly called my itch.
Name: Book 9

text: Rodregas filled his words with the power and the intent behind them.
Name: Book 9

text: My mind, he said.
Name: Book 9

text: My soul to be made one through the flame, he whispered, and then the circle of blood and living organs started to burn and he burned.
Name: Book 9

text: He burned so deeply that no scream crossed his lips.
Name: Book 9

text: He felt every fiber of his being simply burn.
Name: Book 9

text: Rodregas tried to scream, but no sound could pass his lips.
Name: Book 9

text: CHAPTER 2 FROM THE ASHES.
Name: Book 9

text: When Rodregas awoke he was confused about why he was lying on the floor.
Name: Book 9

text: As he opened his eyes he was also alarmed to see Captain Poir looking down at him with a confused and worried expression.
Name: Book 9

text: Captain Poir said, Master Ravenhurr.
Name: Book 9

text: It was a question.
Name: Book 9

text: Rodregas wondered why his captain would think he was the Master.
Name: Book 9

text: And then suddenly it all rushed back to him, all the details of the final ceremony.
Name: Book 9

text: Oh my gods he had burned.
Name: Book 9

text: Rodregas thought in alarm.
Name: Book 9

text: He quickly raised his hand to his eyes, but instead of his scarred, wrinkled hand that should have been seared by burns; there was a powerful smooth hand.
Name: Book 9

text: Rodregas reached up and touched his face.
Name: Book 9

text: Dear Gods, he thought in amazement, the trigger words had worked.
Name: Book 9

text: He had done what he had learned to despise and hate most of all; he had switched into the body of an innocent man.
Name: Book 9

text: I am an Immortalist, thought Rodregas in dismay.
Name: Book 9

text: It had been his only shot at survival, and the young man had already been dead in all ways that mattered, but still it was an act of incredible repugnance to him.
Name: Book 9

text: He thought, Once again I have done what I needed to survive.
Name: Book 9

text: As Rodregas lay on the floor he looked up at the stars and the looming figure of the captain.
Name: Book 9

text: He had to think quickly.
Name: Book 9

text: It was instant death for anyone to interfere with an Immortalist Ascension ceremony.
Name: Book 9

text: It was the most stringent rule enforced by the Guild of the Celestial Path, and therefore the most enforced rule in the Eastern Realm.
Name: Book 9

text: Ah, thank you Captain, I am fine, Rodregas said.
Name: Book 9

text: He instantly realized the captain would know that all was not well.
Name: Book 9

text: Rodregas felt exposed without his armor and said the first thing that came to mind.
Name: Book 9

text: Please, if you can get me my clothes.
Name: Book 9

text: Rodregas waved over to where the sorcerers robe was folded on a small table next to the stairway.
Name: Book 9

text: As he looked over, Rodregas saw that Junnit and Dale had re-bound the AElf maiden with iron and replaced her gag so that she could not use magic on them.
Name: Book 9

text: While they guarded her they also kept her at a distance as if she was somehow strange now.
Name: Book 9

text: To them she was supposed to have been consumed by the ritual, and they seemed a little put off to have the AElf maiden standing there.
Name: Book 9

text: Both were watching their prisoner but also throwing quick concerned looks over to where Rodregas now crouched on the tower roof.
Name: Book 9

text: Captain Poir looked hesitant but then nodded.
Name: Book 9

text: He walked over to the table and gathered up the robes.
Name: Book 9

text: Damn, Rodregas thought he had said please.
Name: Book 9

text: Master Ravenhurr ordered something done; he did not say please to his guard captain.
Name: Book 9

text: As Rodregas stood, Captain Poir held the robe open and he clumsily put it on.
Name: Book 9

text: His movements were awkward in this new larger body.
Name: Book 9

text: His angle was wrong, Rodregas felt like he was standing on a crate.
Name: Book 9

text: Should I order the birthday celebration milord.
Name: Book 9

text: asked the captain.
Name: Book 9

text: The coming celebration had been the talk of speculation for months as well as the object of more than a little betting among the guards.
Name: Book 9

text: Rodregas nodded, his thoughts swirling as he realized that he could use the celebration to his benefit.
Name: Book 9

text: Without looking at the captain he walked toward the stairway, and the captain followed close behind him.
Name: Book 9

text: At the door Rodregas took a deep breath and said, Captain, that ceremony did not go smoothly, but the gods once again proved to favor me, and I wish to be generous with the birthday ceremony.
Name: Book 9

text: Tell the purser to pay everyone an extra months wages today and give everyone a week off to spend as they wish.
Name: Book 9

text: Make sure you tell Purser Stevents to be generous.
Name: Book 9

text: I want all staff rewarded, even the kitchen drudges.
Name: Book 9

text: He finished, hoping it did not sound as halting and made up as he knew it to be.
Name: Book 9

text: Yes, sir, replied Captain Poir, his expression going from a guarded concern to enthusiasm.
Name: Book 9

text: He seemed reassured when Rodregas mentioned Stevents.
Name: Book 9

text: He must have thought either Ravenhurr had been a bit damaged by the ritual or that the young man whose body he now inhabited might still be alive and faking it, obviously the young man would not know about Stevents.
Name: Book 9

text: It must not have occurred to him that his senior sergeant, who had burned in the end, might now inhabit the body.
Name: Book 9

text: The AElf maiden twisted her body against the guards and tried to meet Rodregas eyes and he realized that only she had the magical background to have realized what had happened.
Name: Book 9

text: Just two things, sir, said Captain Poir in a hesitant voice.
Name: Book 9

text: Yes.
Name: Book 9

text: he asked trying to act calm and in control.
Name: Book 9

text: We might lose some guards and probably some of the kitchen drudges if they have money in hand and a whole week off, also we leave ourselves open for theft if we dont keep at least a minimum of guards at the front gate.
Name: Book 9

text: Rodregas relaxed at the mundane nature of the questions.
Name: Book 9

text: True, but I will not stint in thanking the gods for a favorable ceremony.
Name: Book 9

text: Keep a few guards at the gate, but only the minimum needed.
Name: Book 9

text: But that does remind me.
Name: Book 9

text: Release any remaining prisoners and make sure they are fed and clothed, and allow them to make their way back to their homes.
Name: Book 9

text: That has some danger to it, said Captain Poir hurriedly, his expression returning to a look of concern.
Name: Book 9

text: But do as I command, Rodregas stated in his firmest voice.
Name: Book 9

text: Captain Poir nodded and immediately said, As you command, master.
Name: Book 9

text: Rodregas started to open the door to the stairway when another thought hit him, and he turned back to the captain, and said, I need time to adjust.
Name: Book 9

text: Make sure that I am not disturbed in my quarters tonight, but tell Adapt Korin that before he leaves to celebrate, to come up to my room for some last minute instructions.
Name: Book 9

text: Captain Poir responded with his very military, Yes sir.
Name: Book 9

text: Rodregas had to admit while most of the guards were no better trained than a ruffian off the street the captain had served with The Immortal Guards and he was highly trained and disciplined.
Name: Book 9

text: Rodregas had always wondered what had brought a man of his obvious military background to serve Ravenhurr; thank goodness he clearly did not understand the simplest things about magic.
Name: Book 9

text: On the other hand, the AElf maiden clearly had some ideas.
Name: Book 9

text: He was glad she was gagged and not able to speak, and the guards knew better than to release a mage from her bindings until they had to.
Name: Book 9

text: As Rodregas made his way down to the next level, the personal level of Master Ravenhurr, he closed the door to his suite of rooms that covered the whole floor.
Name: Book 9

text: He listened as the other guards made their way down the tower.
Name: Book 9

text: He leaned against the wall and took a deep breath.
Name: Book 9

text: That had been close.
Name: Book 9

text: Rodregas was shocked he had gotten away with it, especially after he had commanded the release of the remaining prisoners.
Name: Book 9

text: He had been twice as generous as he thought Ravenhurr would have been, and Ravenhurr was too practical a man to release the prisoners as part of his celebration.
Name: Book 9

text: The only prisoners in the keeps dungeon were beings that were held for potential use in the ceremony.
Name: Book 9

text: That meant they were of great power or talent.
Name: Book 9

text: The prisoners were too dangerous to release, after Ravenhurr had so pissed them off by their imprisonment.
Name: Book 9

text: But people did not question the order of the sorcerer and master of Raven Keep, so it should work.
Name: Book 9

text: He dared not stay longer than he had to; Rodregas did not believe that he could fool Ravenhurrs guards and servants for long.
Name: Book 9

text: Ravenhurr was a powerful sorcerer who used magic quite casually; it would become quite obvious that Rodregas did not know how to use magic anywhere near Ravenhurrs level.
Name: Book 9

text: As soon as the keep emptied out for the birthday celebration he would make his escape.
Name: Book 9

text: If he missed this opportunity he was not sure when he could try again.
Name: Book 9

text: It was very rare for an Immortalist to leave his tower, and if he were behaving oddly, the guild would send someone to check on him soon.
Name: Book 9

text: They were careful in their control of the kingdom.
Name: Book 9

text: For a while Rodregas just leaned against the cold stone wall.
Name: Book 9

text: Not thinking of anything, there was too much to think about to even start.
Name: Book 9

text: So instead of thinking he simply felt the cool stone wall and it slowly, truly, hit him.
Name: Book 9

text: For some time that simple awareness was enough.
Name: Book 9

text: He was alive, and in a stronger, younger body.
Name: Book 9

text: With the physical essence of the lion now part of his new body, and the magic of the sorcerer Ravenhurr, he would be an extremely talented person.
Name: Book 9

text: That everything had gone so well was simply a god-sent miracle.
Name: Book 9

text: He had rescued the maiden and killed the sorcerer.
Name: Book 9

text: Of course the man's soul and intellect had been destroyed and a lion from the realm of the gods itself had been destroyed.
Name: Book 9

text: It was far from a perfect victory, but Rodregas knew there were never perfect victories.
Name: Book 9

text: He had had more luck in the last half hour than in his entire downtrodden life.
Name: Book 9

text: Then, the next revelation hit him; maybe the Celestial Gods had answered his prayers.
Name: Book 9

text: He had promised the Gods that if he lived, it would become his sworn duty to take down the Immortalists.
Name: Book 9

text: Rodregas new heart seemed to stop for a moment at that thought and a chill ran down his body.
Name: Book 9

text: There were supposed to be well over a hundred Immortalists in the Eastern Realms, each one incredibly powerful.
Name: Book 9

text: What had happened today was pure luck and unlikely to be repeated.
Name: Book 9

text: Trying to tear apart the Immortalists and their powerful guild was a near impossible task.
Name: Book 9

text: Ravenhurr had been known as a powerful Immortalist, but nothing compared to Guild Master Oreintvenir or the Immortalist Guild Dealer Taiga.
Name: Book 9

text: They had been slowly rising in power for centuries on their path to true godhood.
Name: Book 9

text: Rumor was that the Guild Master (and maybe Taiga as well) was close to ascension to true godhood.
Name: Book 9

text: Only two Immortalists had ever succeeded in this task.
Name: Book 9

text: The first was the legendary Accerntorino.
Name: Book 9

text: He was said to have created the Immortalist Ascension ritual and to have been a genius without par.
Name: Book 9

text: The first guild master Accerntorino was also known for his ego.
Name: Book 9

text: Within two decades of his accession he challenged the All-Father Alld for control of the Celestial Pantheon of the Gods.
Name: Book 9

text: Accerntorino claimed he could better lead them to victory over the Daemon Lords of the Infernal Realm.
Name: Book 9

text: But Alld quickly and soundly defeated the upstart Accerntorino.
Name: Book 9

text: What still caused whispers almost 400 years later was his fate; the All-Father had destroyed him.
Name: Book 9

text: Everyone knew stories of various gods that had challenged Alld over the millennia.
Name: Book 9

text: The punishments he had dealt some were horrible and some simply funny or embarrassing.
Name: Book 9

text: A few times he had even driven Gods to join the fallen Daemon Lords in the Infernal Realm.
Name: Book 9

text: But the All-Father did not kill any of these other challengers.
Name: Book 9

text: It was his duty to support the Pantheon, even when they betrayed him.
Name: Book 9

text: Yet his reaction to this newly created god, this incredibly powerful, magic-wielding new immortal, was to simply kill him; and that was the end of it.
Name: Book 9

text: Centuries later, when the next Guild Master had ascended to the Celestial plane, she kept her ego in sharp check.
Name: Book 9

text: The Sorceress Goddess Blodeuwedd was known for how helpful she was to the rest of the Pantheon, especially Alld.
Name: Book 9

text: Rodregas had always assumed that this had been the point of killing Accerntorino; if mortals where going to become Celestial they would do so on the Celestials terms.
Name: Book 9

text: He raised his hand up again and touched his face, feeling its strong, smooth, square jaw.
Name: Book 9

text: The teeth were not the sore, crooked teeth that he had had to be so careful to chew with this morning.
Name: Book 9

text: They were now strong and straight.
Name: Book 9

text: His balding head was now covered in thick long curls, too beautiful for a man in his opinion.
Name: Book 9

text: Rodregas would cut the hair short when he had a chance.
Name: Book 9

text: Ravenhurr had looked for the most perfect physical specimen that he could find and Rodregas was now him.
Name: Book 9

text: Over the years Ravenhurr had collected many very gifted young men.
Name: Book 9

text: These men had won athletic contests and were known for their incredible physical gifts, good looks and sharp wits.
Name: Book 9

text: Ravenhurr tested them for strength, reflexes and dexterity.
Name: Book 9

text: Those that succeeded were further tested for the sharpness of their senses, their intelligence and ability to learn new languages.
Name: Book 9

text: The winner of these tests was rewarded with having his soul and mind ripped out and made into a piece of meat to be filled with the mind, personality, and the very soul of Ravenhurr himself.
Name: Book 9

text: However, this time, instead of Ravenhurr, his old guard sergeant had ended up as a new powerful Immortalist.
Name: Book 9

text: As the cold of the stone chilled his back Rodregas thought about his promise to the Celestial Gods that if he were able to kill Ravenhurr and live, then his new duty would be to fight the Immortalists.
Name: Book 9

text: When all and everyone else had failed him over the years, only his duty had kept Rodregas alive.
Name: Book 9

text: He no longer knew what to do without it.
Name: Book 9

text: His back straightened and he pulled away from the wall that he had slumped against.
Name: Book 9

text: Rodregas lived instead of the man whose body he now lived in.
Name: Book 9

text: He had seen the tragedy of gifted person after gifted person be torn asunder by the Immortalists.
Name: Book 9

text: He hated the Immortalists for their casual destruction and use of people.
Name: Book 9

text: Could he now live in one of these stolen bodies, unless he had a reason.
Name: Book 9

text: The Immortalists and their Guild were evil and needed to be opposed.
Name: Book 9

text: The gods had given him a new duty.
Name: Book 9

text: He stepped away from the wall.
Name: Book 9

text: It was time to get to work.
Name: Book 9

text: CHAPTER 3 THE RAVEN TOWER.
Name: Book 9

text: Rodregas stepped into the masters bedroom for the first time in his twenty years of service in Raven Tower.
Name: Book 9

text: He was unarmed; unarmored and needed to get as far away from Raven Keep as he could before someone noticed that he was not a sorcerer.
Name: Book 9

text: He had spent too much time on the road without money, and he was not going to repeat the experience if he could help it.
Name: Book 9

text: Money would buy him what he needed to start his new life.
Name: Book 9

text: Unfortunately, Ravenhurr had not been interested in material wealth, and what money he did have, he tended to spend on materials needed for his magical ceremonies; still there should be something that he could use.
Name: Book 9

text: The bedroom was not large but this floor also held Ravenhurrs study and a water closet.
Name: Book 9

text: The far wall held a four-poster bed covered by a richly colored duvet.
Name: Book 9

text: To the left of the bed was the door to the water closet and to the left of that a wardrobe.
Name: Book 9

text: Along the connecting wall the fireplace calmly burned.
Name: Book 9

text: To the right of the fireplace was a dresser with a small mirror and at the foot of the bed was an ornamental trunk that matched the wardrobe.
Name: Book 9

text: On first glance there was nothing of much value except for perhaps the candleholder on the dresser.
Name: Book 9

text: It looked like silver, inset with semi-precious stones.
Name: Book 9

text: First, he went to the dresser and started dumping clothes on the ground.
Name: Book 9

text: He was hoping to find some hidden wealth, stashed in the drawers.
Name: Book 9

text: He ended up with a pile of clothes.
Name: Book 9

text: Some were fancy, but none would be of much use on the road and none were worth selling.
Name: Book 9

text: Next, Rodregas went to the wardrobe, which was engraved with the shape of trees and made of a sweet smelling wood.
Name: Book 9

text: It was much more likely to hold something of value.
Name: Book 9

text: He opened the doors to see brightly colored robes, and there on the left was a suit of chain mail.
Name: Book 9

text: Rodregas could feel his smile.
Name: Book 9

text: He reached in and pulled it out.
Name: Book 9

text: The chain mail was light and seemed to flow around his fingers; the links seemed to be made of silver and he recognized it as Mithril.
Name: Book 9

text: Ravenhurr had a suit of Mithril chain; he could feel his heart start to beat in excitement.
Name: Book 9

text: Mithril, a rare magical metal that was stronger than steel but much less heavy and made one of the best light armors.
Name: Book 9

text: AElves, who are not physically as strong as other people, loved the metal.
Name: Book 9

text: Rodregas held it up to himself and then, as excited as he had become, his heart sank as he realized that the suit was both too short and much too slim for him to wear.
Name: Book 9

text: While there were straps to adjust it, his new body was very large and he would never wear the beautiful armor.
Name: Book 9

text: He threw the armor on the bed.
Name: Book 9

text: It might not work for him to wear, but he could get a good amount of money selling such fancy armor.
Name: Book 9

text: It was the first item of real worth that he had found.
Name: Book 9

text: On a shelf above it was another small pile of the silver chain.
Name: Book 9

text: When he pulled it up he saw that it was a helmet, a solid Mithril skullcap with sides of chain mail designed to be connected at the bottom.
Name: Book 9

text: He reached up and pulled it on his head, but even his head was too large for the AElfin style Mithril armor.
Name: Book 9

text: It quickly joined the suit of armor and the candleholder on the bed.
Name: Book 9

text: On the bottom shelf he found a nice pair of boots, not of AElven make.
Name: Book 9

text: Attached were matching grieves, armor designed to protect the lower leg.
Name: Book 9

text: , and a pair of armored gauntlets to compete the set.
Name: Book 9

text: All ended up on the bed.
Name: Book 9

text: Nothing else of interest was in the wardrobe.
Name: Book 9

text: Though the two fanciest robes both heavily embroidered and of Western Silk, also went to the bed.
Name: Book 9

text: Next, he went to the trunk which was made of High Cedar wood and which matched the large wardrobe, but was much more portable.
Name: Book 9

text: Unfortunately, the only items of use in it were several blankets of good quality wool.
Name: Book 9

text: The remaining contents consisted of drawings, pictures and other personal items.
Name: Book 9

text: Rodregas dumped the trunk contents on the floor, sandwiched the armor in the blankets and loaded up the trunk.
Name: Book 9

text: How he was going to cart the trunk out of the tower he did not yet know.
Name: Book 9

text: He went to the door and listened; it seemed to be getting quieter.
Name: Book 9

text: It was the middle of the night and the stir from the ceremony seemed to have subsided, but it was only hours until dawn when everyone would be heading out to celebrate the new birth of Ravenhurr.
Name: Book 9

text: Not a true celebration for most; as their lord and master, he was more feared than loved.
Name: Book 9

text: Rodregas locked the door to prevent a surprise.
Name: Book 9

text: He should have done that before; it was sloppy of him not to take such a simple precaution.
Name: Book 9

text: Asking Captain Poir to send up Adapt Korin had been totally unplanned.
Name: Book 9

text: He had been dreaming of killing Korin for all the 18 years that he had served in the tower.
Name: Book 9

text: The Sorcerer Ravenhurr had been an immoral monster that used those around him for his own selfish desires.
Name: Book 9

text: But Adapt Korin was of a more casual evil; he never passed up the opportunity to hurt those around him, physically or emotionally.
Name: Book 9

text: Ravenhurr had existed in the same body for the full eighteen years of Rodregas service, and was hundreds of years old.
Name: Book 9

text: In all his years serving in the tower Ravenhurr had only tried to hold the ceremony three times, each time abandoning the attempt due to the lack of a celestial animal.
Name: Book 9

text: A celestial animal was extremely rare, but required as part of the ceremony for Ravenhurrs next step up in power.
Name: Book 9

text: In contrast, his assistant, the Adapt Korin, had been going though bodies constantly.
Name: Book 9

text: Worse, he seemed to take great delight in letting people know what fate awaited them.
Name: Book 9

text: Rape and torture of the victims were common occurrences with Korin.
Name: Book 9

text: And Rodregas had dreamed of killing him almost from the start.
Name: Book 9

text: Rodregas had hated Ravenhurr and knew that his Master could have stopped his assistants actions with a word.
Name: Book 9

text: Ravenhurr had been simply too powerful for Rodregas to dream of destroying.
Name: Book 9

text: He was stronger, faster, and smarter than him to the point where even dreams of fighting him had never crossed his mind until this past week.
Name: Book 9

text: However, his assistant Korin had only been an Immortalist for a few decades; his victims and his power were still purely mortal.
Name: Book 9

text: Rodregas had known that in a fair fight he could kill him.
Name: Book 9

text: Korin was no warrior, and his actions spoke of cowardice when Korin hurt those who had no chance in a fight against him.
Name: Book 9

text: Rodregas had been trying to get him alone, where he could kill him without blame, for years.
Name: Book 9

text: Rodregas went over and reached down to grab the bottom of the heavily made bed, and almost fell over when the bed lifted far more easily than expected.
Name: Book 9

text: The sound of wood screeched as weight switched to the back legs of the bed and then moved at his awkward action, and the top of the columns smashed against the plaster ceiling.
Name: Book 9

text: Rodregas carefully lowered the bed back down; as the bed settled back to the floor he was covered by a light dusting of plaster from the damaged ceiling.

frame.Frame: Cause  change  of  position  on  a  scale

Name: Book 9

text: Was Rodregas really that strong.
Name: Book 9

text: Or was the bed just lighter than it looked.
Name: Book 9

text: He went back over to the trunk and lifted it up; it to went up too easily and felt strangely light.
Name: Book 9

text: Next he went over the dresser.
Name: Book 9

text: Rodregas had known that the physical essence of the celestial lion was in his body and that all of his physical attributes would be improved, but the strength of the Immortalist was not common knowledge; you just heard that they were long lived and never got sick.
Name: Book 9

text: They used magic against their foes not swords, and they seldom got involved in physical struggles.
Name: Book 9

text: Of course Rodregas had known that in The Immortal Guard of the Guild the most loyal and powerful of their officers were given enhanced bodies, but he thought their power lay in their magical sigils.
Name: Book 9

text: His new body was very large and very muscular, and much stronger than he would have guessed.
Name: Book 9

text: Rodregas lifted his right arm and curled it into a tight muscle.
Name: Book 9

text: He felt the biceps with his free hand.
Name: Book 9

text: The texture under the skin felt like bundles of large, powerful cables.
Name: Book 9

text: He felt his face break into a smile; he had seen this face smile when it had been a prisoner.
Name: Book 9

text: The smile the prisoner had worn was a very open charming smile.
Name: Book 9

text: The smile he felt on his face now had little resemblance to the one he remembered seeing, though without looking in the mirror he had no way of knowing for sure.
Name: Book 9

text: Come on up, Korin.
Name: Book 9

text: I have a surprise for you, Rodregas whispered under his breath.
Name: Book 9

text: He went around the room one final time poking around for anything else of note and, finding nothing, went over to the door to the water closet.
Name: Book 9

text: Inside he first tested out the plumbing, finding the experience both new and familiar.
Name: Book 9

text: He also had a chance to examine his own plumbing, and was pleased with the results; his new body was large and powerfully built even in places that most people would not see.
Name: Book 9

text: The only thing of use in the water closet was a shaving kit which Rodregas added to the trunk.
Name: Book 9

text: Next he went to the study door only to find it locked.
Name: Book 9

text: He looked for a key but there was nothing.
Name: Book 9

text: He guessed that it was locked by magic and required a magic word or incantation to open the lock.
Name: Book 9

text: He pushed and pulled on the door, but it was solidly made and there was nothing to get a good hold of to test his new strength.
Name: Book 9

text: He looked around for something to use as a pry bar; next to the fireplace was a poker.
Name: Book 9

text: He grabbed it and forced it into the crack were a normal door would have its catch.
Name: Book 9

text: He got it wedged in good but then stopped and went over to the outside door and opening it, listened for anyone nearby before going back inside the room.
Name: Book 9

text: He carefully closed the door behind him; the sound of him breaking down the study door would ring loud in the predawn silence, but his need for money was too great.
Name: Book 9

text: What he had found would be worth some good coin but finding a trader that would give him its worth would take time.
Name: Book 9

text: He needed to find silver and gold.
Name: Book 9

text: Rodregas muffled the door with a blanket the best he could and then with a violent shove and twist of the fireplace poker, shattered open the study door.
Name: Book 9

text: He held his breath.
Name: Book 9

text: He listened but heard no signs of approaching guards.
Name: Book 9

text: They had probably heard something but none would question the master, or at least the person they thought was the master.
Name: Book 9

text: He pulled his way in through the shattered remainder of the door; in the middle of the room was a large round table with several books and papers spread out on it.
Name: Book 9

text: Next to the open windows was a very nice desk with a very comfortable looking chair; next to the fireplace were several larger overstuffed and even more comfortable looking chairs.
Name: Book 9

text: There were not as many books as Rodregas had thought there would be; only one wall was covered in shelves and miscellaneous piles of scrolls and other items.
Name: Book 9

text: Next to the desk there was a fancy set of shelves with glass covers to protect them.
Name: Book 9

text: He went over to the glass enclosed shelves; the books looked richly made but old.
Name: Book 9

text: Books of sorcery would sell very well indeed.
Name: Book 9

text: The glass covers were locked, so again he muffled the sound with the blanket and forced the cabinet doors open.
Name: Book 9

text: With each cabinet door the glass broke.
Name: Book 9

text: He tried to open the cabinet doors without breaking the glass.
Name: Book 9

text: But, whatever magic locks were in force were just too secure.
Name: Book 9

text: So, he had to use brute strength to shatter the doors one by one.
Name: Book 9

text: Several of the books fell during his struggles with the cabinet.
Name: Book 9

text: Rodregas reached down and grabbed a couple of them, and then dropped them right back to the ground in shock as evil licked his hand.
Name: Book 9

text: He shook the feeling off his hand and went back to the water closet and washed it in the water basin.
Name: Book 9

text: Of course he knew there was nothing physically on his hand, but he also knew that water was a natural purifier and disrupted many magical influences.
Name: Book 9

text: What he had felt was simply disgusting.
Name: Book 9

text: Why would a book, no matter what its contents, have such a feel to it.
Name: Book 9

text: He walked back to the book and got down on the ground.
Name: Book 9

text: Without actually touching it, Rodregas slowly ran his fingertips along the binder of the book.
Name: Book 9

text: While the feeling was not as strong as when he had held it, clearly the feeling of what could only be described as evil emanated from the book.
Name: Book 9

text: Was this feeling truly coming from the book or was this some new ability of his new body to sense the nature of the books contents.
Name: Book 9

text: Rodregas got up and walked over to the bookshelf.
Name: Book 9

text: He closed his eyes and, trying not to touch, lightly ran his hands close to the row of books.
Name: Book 9

text: Quickly he realized that with some books he felt nothing.
Name: Book 9

text: Other books seemed to buzz with energy but gave off no bad feelings.
Name: Book 9

text: Still others had a bad odor of decay or foulness that made him want to cover his nose and pull away.
Name: Book 9

text: In truth there was no smell, but simply a feeling.
Name: Book 9

text: Rodregas made a quick decision to trust this new ability and to take action.
Name: Book 9

text: He had the impression that these foul books were of the most evil soul-stealing magic of the Immortalists.
Name: Book 9

text: He opened up the fireplace and started to chuck all the evil books into the fire with the poker.
Name: Book 9

text: The ones from which magic radiated he placed into the trunk; true books of magic would sell nicely.
Name: Book 9

text: The process of sorting the books and then getting them to burn took several hours and he started to feel how long it had been since his new body had slept.
Name: Book 9

text: The sound of the tower was changing, the first sounds of the kitchen crew getting ready for the morning.
Name: Book 9

text: Still he kept at it, though there seemed to be nothing else of wealth in the room.
Name: Book 9

text: He was determined to see the evil books burn.
Name: Book 9

text: They held the secrets to the Immortalist art and other dark magic.
Name: Book 9

text: Leaving them would only lead to another person rising in Ravenhurrs place.
Name: Book 9

text: Several of the foulest books seemed to refuse to burn but the flames eventually consumed all, just as they had consumed Ravenhurr.
Name: Book 9

text: Finally, the last of the dark books of magic were burned, and the few remaining books that felt of magic but lacked the evil stench of the others were packed in the trunk.
Name: Book 9

text: Only six volumes had been free of the stench, while over forty were burned.
Name: Book 9

text: The sun was now streaming into the room and he was feeling the lack of sleep.
Name: Book 9

text: He decided that it would take a while for the keep to empty out as everyone went into town to celebrate Ravenhurrs new birthday, and he stretched out on the big four-poster bed.
Name: Book 9

text: He had thought that he would struggle to sleep, but instead immediately found deep sleep.
Name: Book 9

text: In what felt like only a few minutes later, he struggled from deep within his dreams to the sound of a polite knock on the door.
Name: Book 9

text: He looked around for a second, confused by his surroundings until memories returned.
Name: Book 9

text: The sunlight through the windows was now indirect so he guessed it to be mid or even late afternoon.
Name: Book 9

text: Again came the polite knock; no one would dare such persistence without direct orders from Ravenhurr.
Name: Book 9

text: It had to be Adapt Korin.
Name: Book 9

text: He nearly leaped off the bed and looked for a sword but of course there was none.
Name: Book 9

text: He stepped in front of the bedroom door as he quickly did his best to close the broken study door.
Name: Book 9

text: He quietly unlocked it and stepped back and said simply, Enter, and waited for the Adapt to come inside.
Name: Book 9

text: Korin came into the room with a relaxed step that showed him to be much more comfortable than Rodregas was.
Name: Book 9

text: Korin was a good looking man.
Name: Book 9

text: It was always weird with him.
Name: Book 9

text: He changed bodies so often that you always felt like you were meeting someone new, but it was not long before you realized that it was Korin.
Name: Book 9

text: He wore a slim male body that was well-built, not much over 20 years old, with blue eyes and blond hair.
Name: Book 9

text: Rodregas was not sure what to say to him so he stood there simply looking.
Name: Book 9

text: He was the Master and it would not be surprising for Ravenhurr to keep him waiting for a few minutes.
Name: Book 9

text: Korin waited patiently, seemingly at ease with what Rodregas would assume to be strange behavior by Master Ravenhurr.
Name: Book 9

text: Are you ready to leave and celebrate my new birth.
Name: Book 9

text: Adept Korin nodded politely and said, Yes, Master, the gods favor your desire to imitate their celestial glory.
Name: Book 9

text: Rodregas nodded back in acknowledgement and said, And have you found any new bodies who you would like to take.
Name: Book 9

text: That question seemed to surprise him, but Korin smiled and said, No, Master.
Name: Book 9

text: I have been too busy working on my studies.
Name: Book 9

text: Korin now looked at him with a surprised expression and an eyebrow slightly raised.
Name: Book 9

text: Rodregas wondered if he had said something wrong.
Name: Book 9

text: While he had seen the two interact for some years, he really did not know what was appropriate for him to say in such a circumstance.
Name: Book 9

text: Rodregas knew that he did not have the skills for pretending he was a powerful Immortalist sorcerer, so he said, How many people have you killed during the past year Korin.
Name: Book 9

text: And how many others have you raped or tortured.
Name: Book 9

text: he asked, trying to keep a calm voice.
Name: Book 9

text: Now Korin looked very surprised and he started looking around.
Name: Book 9

text: Rodregas saw that Korin noticed the study door, though he was working hard to not show it.
Name: Book 9

text: Rodregas repeated his question.
Name: Book 9

text: I am not sure, Korin said.
Name: Book 9

text: For us to truly become divine we must of course develop our skills.
Name: Book 9

text: As Korin answered the question he took a step back.
Name: Book 9

text: Rodregas quickly stepped forward and pushed him hard against the wall.
Name: Book 9

text: Korin hit with a hard smack and slid to the ground, hurt, but not badly.
Name: Book 9

text: Rodregas slammed the door closed and relocked it.
Name: Book 9

text: Then he quickly reached down and covered Korins mouth, pulled him up, and slipped behind him.
Name: Book 9

text: Rodregas saw Korins bulging eyes as he tried to get a better look at his captor.
Name: Book 9

text: Korin struggled but not as if his life depended on it.
Name: Book 9

text: He was probably confused.
Name: Book 9

text: The image of the day that Rodregas had started to hate him came back.
Name: Book 9

text: A family of AElves had been taken prisoner; they were just common AElves with no real magic.
Name: Book 9

text: Korin was interested in the father, a good-looking man.
Name: Book 9

text: The wife was equally beautiful and they had a slim child named Jorin.
Name: Book 9

text: Rodregas had taken Jorin under his wing.
Name: Book 9

text: He had only been working at Raven Keep for a little over a year at the time and was still learning the names of the prisoners.
Name: Book 9

text: Rodregas had thought that Jorin was a good lad, well behaved and bright, and his eyes were eager for signs of hope.
Name: Book 9

text: Rodregas brought him extra food and words of reassurance.
Name: Book 9

text: Ravenhurr had no need for him nor his mother, and he had seen other prisoners who were not of use set free.
Name: Book 9

text: Rodregas had thought that Jorin would also be set free.
Name: Book 9

text: Two months went by and Rodregas had developed a strong fondness for the boy; a few of the guards made jokes that Rodregas had a new pet.
Name: Book 9

text: Rodregas was used to the rough humor of soldiers and let such jokes roll off.
Name: Book 9

text: The night came when the father was taken for the ceremony.
Name: Book 9

text: Rodregas was on guard duty when Korin came down in his new body.
Name: Book 9

text: The poor lad had stared at the man who had been his father, saying nothing, but tears ran down his cheeks.
Name: Book 9

text: The apprentice Immortalist had then proceeded to rape the mother.
Name: Book 9

text: The Adapt was rough and the act was violent and Korin, in his new body, clearly enjoyed the violence more than the sex.
Name: Book 9

text: After he had finished with the mother, he had the guards release the boy who had run over to his sobbing bleeding mother.
Name: Book 9

text: In a fatherly gesture Korin had kissed the boy on the cheek and, wrapping his hands around the boys head in a slow loving gesture, made a quick yank and broke Joins neck.
Name: Book 9

text: The next day the guards released the young AElfin widow.
Name: Book 9

text: Rodregas had helped drag her beyond the gates.
Name: Book 9

text: She lay there not moving, limp though alive; she was dead in every way that mattered.
Name: Book 9

text: Rodregas went back into the keep without looking back; he never knew what had happened to her after that.
Name: Book 9

text: After dreaming every night about killing him, Rodregas now had Korin in his grip.
Name: Book 9

text: It was time to end Korins vile pestilence on the world.
Name: Book 9

text: Rodregas got behind him with his right hand covering his mouth, and with his left took a firm grip on the top of his head.
Name: Book 9

text: Rodregas leaned over to his ear and whispered You probably dont remember, but you killed a boy named Jorin by snapping his neck, and payback is a bitch.
Name: Book 9

text: Snapping a grown mans neck is quite hard.
Name: Book 9

text: Rodregas had never done it; he had learned that there were better ways to kill a man than trying to break his spine with bare hands.
Name: Book 9

text: But with the memory of Korin breaking Jorins neck, adrenaline pounded in his new arms.
Name: Book 9

text: This was justice long overdue.
Name: Book 9

text: With a quick movement of his arms and the haunting memory of the sounds of crunching and popping from all those years ago, he twisted Korins head nearly all the way around.
Name: Book 9

text: Rodregas held his body as it spasmed wildly for a moment.
Name: Book 9

text: Then the Adapt went still and limp; and Rodregas dropped him to the floor.
Name: Book 9

text: Korins body hit the floor and started to empty itself.
Name: Book 9

text: Gods, he thought and asked out loud to no one, What did he eat this morning.
Name: Book 9

text: He grabbed the body and dragged it into the water closet and dropped it into the small bronze tub.

frame.Frame: Cause  change  of  position  on  a  scale

Name: Book 9

text: Rodregas started to leave and then saw Korins purse; the Adapt was dressed for travel and Rodregas had yet to find even a single coin in the Masters chambers.
Name: Book 9

text: He reached down and took the purse off his belt.
Name: Book 9

text: Rodregas opened it to find only a few silvers.
Name: Book 9

text: He knew Korin should have more.
Name: Book 9

text: He opened his shirt and, as he suspected, another purse hung from his neck.
Name: Book 9

text: It was of flat leather and inside it were twelve pieces of silver and a small book.
Name: Book 9

text: Rodregas tentatively touched the book and it buzzed slightly of magic.
Name: Book 9

text: It held no foulness so he tossed it into the trunk.
Name: Book 9

text: He added the coin purses to the robe he was wearing.
Name: Book 9

text: He still needed more hard money and some decent clothes.
Name: Book 9

text: Rodregas looked out the window to see a few people leaving the keep grounds, and a few still hanging around the yard.
Name: Book 9

text: He knew he could not leave without everyone seeing him.
Name: Book 9

text: He searched the rest of the study in the daylight.
Name: Book 9

text: He found nothing of real use until he pulled a drawer completely out of the desk and found a false back to the drawer.
Name: Book 9

text: He found it was holding a purple silk purse containing eight pieces of gold and two of silver.
Name: Book 9

text: Now he had the money he needed to be on the run.
Name: Book 9

text: After forcing himself to wait until the last visible person left the main gate, Rodregas grabbed the trunk and went to the stairs.
Name: Book 9

text: He listened quietly, and hearing nothing, he set the trunk down and quietly walked down the stairs.
Name: Book 9

text: The next floor housed the laboratory.
Name: Book 9

text: The door was locked and he did not want to break it down until he was sure everyone had left.
Name: Book 9

text: The next floor down was the main floor; He stepped out to the main hall and listened.
Name: Book 9

text: He heard nothing but his stomach rumble; he was very hungry and knew that he should eat.
Name: Book 9

text: He was already in the main hall; the room to the right was the kitchen.
Name: Book 9

text: He stepped into the kitchen but then came to a sudden stop.
Name: Book 9

text: Standing next to one of the sinks was a very old, very dirty kitchen drudge slowly peeling a potato.
Name: Book 9

text: She looked up at him in surprise, and with a hint of fear.
Name: Book 9

text: Rodregas raised his hand up in a peaceful motion.
Name: Book 9

text: She probably had nowhere else to go.
Name: Book 9

text: He ignored her and went to the cabinets and the cold box.
Name: Book 9

text: He got out cheese and bread, found some fruit and had a good simple meal.
Name: Book 9

text: He would need to pack as much food as possible for his journey.
Name: Book 9

text: The old kitchen drudge was still peeling the same potato when he left the kitchen.
Name: Book 9

text: Freshly fed and feeling better for it, Rodregas went across the main hall and entered the door opposite the kitchen into the barracks section of the keep.
Name: Book 9

text: The place was about as messy as he had ever seen it; the normal tidiness demanded by Captain Poir had apparently been put aside in excitement over the chance to take some time off for the celebration.
Name: Book 9

text: His personal bunk and trunk were a mess.
Name: Book 9

text: His good blanket was missing, as was his spare pair of boots and most of his other belongings.
Name: Book 9

text: Clearly, the rest of the guards had thought him dead and made free with his stuff.
Name: Book 9

text: Rodregas reached into the trunk but all that was left in there were a few bits of trash, a few candle stubs, some scraps of paper and a bit of cloth.
Name: Book 9

text: He reached down and picked up the small piece of cloth and held it up.
Name: Book 9

text: He stared for some time at the design sewn into it, and then stuck it into his outer purse.
Name: Book 9

text: He had a strong urge to clean up his bunk and leave the area in the order it deserved, but that would be too big of a hint of what had happened.
Name: Book 9

text: So, he was careful to leave it as it was; the longer they thought he was Ravenhurr the better.
Name: Book 9

text: He then walked past the rest of the wooden cots of the barracks to the back where the captains room was.
Name: Book 9

text: The captains room, unlike the outer barracks, was spotless and in perfect order.
Name: Book 9

text: He searched through the captains pair of trunks and found some clothes that fit him, though tightly.
Name: Book 9

text: The captain had been a big man but not as large as Rodregas now was.
Name: Book 9

text: Still the soft linen shirt of light brown, which he knew had been loose on the captain, was much more comfortable than the wizard robe he had been wearing.
Name: Book 9

text: Unfortunately none of the pants would fit.
Name: Book 9

text: Poir, though a large man, had skinny legs.
Name: Book 9

text: Rodregas felt ridiculous wearing only a linen shirt and his coin purses as he stepped to the armory door.
Name: Book 9

text: The door was built of massive slabs of iron oak.
Name: Book 9

text: Rodregas reached up and pulled the emergency key from the crack at the right of the door.
Name: Book 9

text: Due to his status as a senior sergeant, he knew where the key was kept.
Name: Book 9

text: Once the door was open, he stepped inside.
Name: Book 9

text: Immediately, his eyes went to a long side bench where several new pieces of armor were piled up.
Name: Book 9

text: These would be some of the more recent pieces not yet sorted or sold off for not being of use to the guard.
Name: Book 9

text: Captain Poir had a tendency to leave some of the better equipment there for long periods, just in case they might prove useful at a later date.
Name: Book 9

text: Most of the armor was average civilian crap, but he quickly found several large pieces of leather scale armor that were his size.
Name: Book 9

text: From the good fit he surmised that it had been the property of the original owner of his new body.
Name: Book 9

text: The armor was braided leather with steel scales attached; he quickly tried it on and found it to be a perfect fit.
Name: Book 9

text: It was probably custom made and was solid, if unspectacular, quality armor.
Name: Book 9

text: The braided, lacquered leather reinforced with the steel scales provided decent protection for most fights.
Name: Book 9

text: This style of armor was vulnerable to a highly skilled swordsman.
Name: Book 9

text: But for someone wanting some protection from the dangers of the road, it was better than most civilian armor.
Name: Book 9

text: There were matching pants and even boots.
Name: Book 9

text: He quickly dressed and felt much better once armored.
Name: Book 9

text: He had spent most of his adult life in armor; he just could not relax when he wore only clothes.
Name: Book 9

text: Rodregas then looked around; the keep armory was pretty basic with casks of arrows and spears, and some of the older used short swords and bows on the wall.
Name: Book 9

text: There were only two truly powerful weapons like those used by a member of the Immortal Guards  the soldiers that enforced the rule of the Immortalist Guild of the Celestial Path who ruled all the Eastern Kingdoms and neither of these weapons were kept in the armory.
Name: Book 9

text: He looked over to the short swords laying on one of the tables and picked two of them up; they felt a little weird.
Name: Book 9

text: The swords were too light and the balance seemed off as he took a few practice strokes.
Name: Book 9

text: There was a large two-handed great sword, a weapon that was difficult to handle if you were not very strong, and its sheath matched the armor he now wore.
Name: Book 9

text: Rodregas picked it up and took a few swings and found that it was not as clumsy as he thought it would be.
Name: Book 9

text: It was of average make, and he did not like such large swords.
Name: Book 9

text: The weight provided a lot of momentum and power for a strike, but if you missed it was hard to recover and very easy to leave yourself wide open for a counter strike from your opponent.
Name: Book 9

text: It looked like the guards had gone to celebrate his birthday by taking most of the better armor and weapons with them.
Name: Book 9

text: Rodregas grabbed a shield as well, and a barrel of the best looking arrows and carried them to the front entrance.
Name: Book 9

text: There was probably money in the pursers office, but he knew that the door, as well as the room was rigged with poison needles and other traps, both mundane and magical.
Name: Book 9

text: Rodregas had the impression that Ravenhurr had spent most of his wealth of late on the Dire Cats.
Name: Book 9

text: After Rodregas recent generosity, he did not want to take the risk of dying for a nearly empty treasure box.
Name: Book 9

text: He looked out of the entrance, over to the gate and up to the top of the wall where a small tower provided cover.
Name: Book 9

text: There, one of the few guards left should be watching the front gate.
Name: Book 9

text: Also kept in the tower were two of the nicest weapons Rodregas had ever seen: a pair of recurve bows of Wood Nymph created black yew.
Name: Book 9

text: There was no way they would have been taken.
Name: Book 9

text: There were standing orders to kill anyone who tried to remove them.
Name: Book 9

text: Rodregas was not a very good bowman, but he was definitely going to try to bring them with him.
Name: Book 9

text: He peeked out of the main doors and looked around the open keep.
Name: Book 9

text: The stables were to the left and the gate was to the right.
Name: Book 9

text: The courtyard was not large.
Name: Book 9

text: He could not see anyone, but he knew there would be at least two guards left: one at the gate and one in the watchtower over the gate.
Name: Book 9

text: In front of the stable was a large bony horse, dappled in brown and white.
Name: Book 9

text: Rodregas thought her name was Tory or Torin, he could not remember which.
Name: Book 9

text: She was an older horse, in her early twenties, and was known for her mild manor.
Name: Book 9

text: She was saddled and ready to go, evidently she was Korins planned mount.
Name: Book 9

text: Rodregas took a deep breath and calmly walked out of the keep and over to the stables.
Name: Book 9

text: It was not large, ordinarily holding only about a dozen horses.
Name: Book 9

text: He looked around to find that it was emptied out, except for the two carriage horses.
Name: Book 9

text: They must have been left in case Ravenhurr wished to travel, which would be unlikely with all his guards and servants scattered over the town, but good servants did not take their masters transport from him.
Name: Book 9
